triples.name: Fitness (biology)
triples.relevance: Fitness effects of mutations are the primary metric used to quantify adaptive landscape changes.

triples.name: Mutation
triples.relevance: Mutations are the source of genetic variation analyzed to determine fitness landscape properties.

triples.name: Fitness landscape
triples.relevance: The adaptive landscape concept is central to understanding how fitness effects vary across genetic backgrounds and ecological conditions.

triples.name: Ecotype
triples.relevance: The paper studies two ecotypes (L and S strains) that emerged within the LTEE community.

triples.name: Escherichia coli
triples.relevance: E. coli is the model organism used in the Long-Term Evolution Experiment and all fitness measurements.

triples.name: E. coli long-term evolution experiment
triples.relevance: The LTEE is the specific experimental platform from which the nascent bacterial community was sampled.

triples.name: Transposable element
triples.relevance: The paper engineers genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries as a novel method to measure fitness effects of gene knockouts.

triples.name: Gene knockout
triples.relevance: Gene knockouts are the technique used to measure invasion fitness effects across all genes in the study.

triples.name: Epistasis
triples.relevance: Epistatic effects (genetic interactions) combine with ecological effects to shape the adaptive landscape.

triples.name: Adaptation
triples.relevance: Evolutionary adaptation patterns are revealed through correlations between fitness effects and evolutionary outcomes.
